snippet: The justices are hungry for the data in amicus briefs, but a law professor argues that some of the briefs cite questionable materials.
abstract: Adam Liptak Sidebar column; Supreme Court justices often rely on amicus briefs for factual information on a case, but assertions in some briefs are backed up by unreliable sources like blogs or emails; Justice Stephen G Breyer, in 2013 decision, cited an amicus brief to establish that American libraries hold 200 million books that were published abroad, figure that came from a blog post.
lead_paragraph: The justices are hungry for the data in amicus briefs, but a law professor argues that some of the briefs cite questionable materials.

headline.print_headline: Seeking Facts, Justices Settle for What Briefs Tell Them
headline.main: Seeking Facts, Justices Settle for What Briefs Tell Them
